name: Evolution of colour
description: From stenciling film frames through to the survival of Technicolor after Hollywood stopped using it, this Constellation links early cinema to some of the world's greatest films.

key_work.title: Stencil colouring
key_work.brief_description: When Alexandre Volkoff brought the story of history’s greatest lover to the screen in Casanova (1927), he definitely needed colour. Pathé Frères developed a stencil technqiue for colouring films that brought Casanova’s costumes alive and colour to his lovers’ cheeks.

constellations_primary.name: Evolution of colour
constellations_primary.description: From stenciling film frames through to the survival of Technicolor after Hollywood stopped using it, this Constellation links early cinema to some of the world's greatest films.

start.title: A Visit to the Seaside
start.brief_description: The first successful motion picture in the Kinemacolor system, this eight minute short from George Albert Smith showed people in Brighton, England doing everyday activities. Kinemacolor later influenced and was then replaced by Technicolor.

constellations_other.name: Evolution of colour
constellations_other.description: From stenciling film frames through to the survival of Technicolor after Hollywood stopped using it, this Constellation links early cinema to some of the world's greatest films.

end.title: The Gulf Between
end.creator_credit: J. Parker Read Jr. and Anthony Paul Kelly
end.brief_description: The Gulf Between is a 1917 American comedy drama film that was the first motion picture made in Technicolor, the fourth feature-length color movie, and the first feature-length color movie produced in the United States.

constellations_other.name: Evolution of colour
constellations_other.description: From stenciling film frames through to the survival of Technicolor after Hollywood stopped using it, this Constellation links early cinema to some of the world's greatest films.

links.description: Kinemacolor was an important influence on the popular Technicolor system, which went through several developments. The first, Process 1, used red and green filters like Kinemacolor. The only filmed produced in Process 1 Technicolor is The Gulf Between.

start.title: Loves of Casanova
start.creator_credit: Ciné-Alliance, Deulig Film, Société des Cinéromans, Noë Bloch, Alexandre Volkoff, Ivan Mosjoukine and Norbert Falk
start.brief_description: Republic of Venice, 1760. Pursued by a vengeful husband, the intrepid womanizer Casanova, who symbolizes the decline of the city and its fall into debauchery, manages to escape and, by a circuitous route, arrives in Saint Petersburg, where he will be involved in the many plots that threaten the throne of Czar Peter III…

constellations_other.name: Evolution of colour
constellations_other.description: From stenciling film frames through to the survival of Technicolor after Hollywood stopped using it, this Constellation links early cinema to some of the world's greatest films.

end.title: A Visit to the Seaside
end.brief_description: The first successful motion picture in the Kinemacolor system, this eight minute short from George Albert Smith showed people in Brighton, England doing everyday activities. Kinemacolor later influenced and was then replaced by Technicolor.

constellations_other.name: Evolution of colour
constellations_other.description: From stenciling film frames through to the survival of Technicolor after Hollywood stopped using it, this Constellation links early cinema to some of the world's greatest films.

links.description: Casanova was coloured by Pathé Frères’ stencil process, which used a template for each colour and applied it frame-by-frame. Almost 20 years earlier, the British Kinemacolour system used red and green filters to colour A Visit to the Seaside.

start.title: The Gulf Between
start.creator_credit: J. Parker Read Jr. and Anthony Paul Kelly
start.brief_description: The Gulf Between is a 1917 American comedy drama film that was the first motion picture made in Technicolor, the fourth feature-length color movie, and the first feature-length color movie produced in the United States.

constellations_other.name: Evolution of colour
constellations_other.description: From stenciling film frames through to the survival of Technicolor after Hollywood stopped using it, this Constellation links early cinema to some of the world's greatest films.

end.title: Becky Sharp
end.brief_description: Adapted from a play that drew inspiration from William Makepeace Thackeray’s novel “Vanity Fair”, the film explores the English class system during the era of the Napoleonic Wars, but more importantly, is the first feature to use three-strip Technicolor.

constellations_other.name: Over the Technicolor rainbow
constellations_other.description: This Constellation explores the beginning and legacy of Technicolor and was created by Swinburne Cinema and Screen Studies students Adam Virgona and Kristian Vass.

constellations_other.name: Evolution of colour
constellations_other.description: From stenciling film frames through to the survival of Technicolor after Hollywood stopped using it, this Constellation links early cinema to some of the world's greatest films.

links.description: The three strip Technicolor method added a blue filter to the red and green system, bringing further depth and colour saturation. Becky Sharp was the first feature filmed in three-strip Technicolor.

start.title: Becky Sharp
start.brief_description: Adapted from a play that drew inspiration from William Makepeace Thackeray’s novel “Vanity Fair”, the film explores the English class system during the era of the Napoleonic Wars, but more importantly, is the first feature to use three-strip Technicolor.

constellations_other.description: This Constellation explores the beginning and legacy of Technicolor and was created by Swinburne Cinema and Screen Studies students Adam Virgona and Kristian Vass.

end.title: The Godfather: Part II
end.creator_credit: Francis Ford Coppola, Theadora Van Runkle, Fred Roos, Gray Frederickson, Mona Skager, Paramount Pictures, The Coppola Company and Dean Tavoularis
end.headline_credit: United States and United States of America, 1974
end.brief_description: Both a prequel and sequel to The Godfather, Francis Ford Coppola’s follow up continues the modern-day tale of Don Michael Corleone (Al Pacino), alongside the story of young Vito Corleone (Robert De Niro) fleeing Italy and making his way through the mafia.

constellations_other.name: Evolution of colour
constellations_other.description: From stenciling film frames through to the survival of Technicolor after Hollywood stopped using it, this Constellation links early cinema to some of the world's greatest films.

links.description: Technicolor’s popularity declined from the late-1950s because it took longer to make prints than it did from the one-strip colour processes that had been developed. One of the last Hollywood hits printed with Technicolor was The Godfather: Part II.

start.title: The Godfather: Part II
start.creator_credit: Francis Ford Coppola, Theadora Van Runkle, Fred Roos, Gray Frederickson, Mona Skager, Paramount Pictures, The Coppola Company and Dean Tavoularis
start.headline_credit: United States and United States of America, 1974
start.brief_description: Both a prequel and sequel to The Godfather, Francis Ford Coppola’s follow up continues the modern-day tale of Don Michael Corleone (Al Pacino), alongside the story of young Vito Corleone (Robert De Niro) fleeing Italy and making his way through the mafia.

constellations_other.name: Evolution of colour
constellations_other.description: From stenciling film frames through to the survival of Technicolor after Hollywood stopped using it, this Constellation links early cinema to some of the world's greatest films.

end.title: Ju Dou
end.creator_credit: Zhang Yimou, Zhi-an Zhang, Hu Jian, Wenze Zhang, Yasuyoshi Tokuma, China Film Co-Production Corporation, Cao Juiping, Xia Rujin and Liu Heng
end.brief_description: Zhang Yimou’s Ju Dou is the first Chinese film to be nominated for an Academy Award for Best Foreign Language film. Starring Gong Li as a young woman trapped in a loveless marriage, this sensual and striking film is aided by its vivid use of Technicolor.

constellations_other.name: Evolution of colour
constellations_other.description: From stenciling film frames through to the survival of Technicolor after Hollywood stopped using it, this Constellation links early cinema to some of the world's greatest films.

links.description: When the British Technicolor factory shut down, its equipment was shipped to China, where filmmakers used Technicolor in the 1990s. Zhang Yimou used the process in Ju Dou, with the vibrant colours rendered in Technicolor intrinsic to the film’s symbolism.

start.title: Ju Dou
start.creator_credit: Zhang Yimou, Zhi-an Zhang, Hu Jian, Wenze Zhang, Yasuyoshi Tokuma, China Film Co-Production Corporation, Cao Juiping, Xia Rujin and Liu Heng
start.brief_description: Zhang Yimou’s Ju Dou is the first Chinese film to be nominated for an Academy Award for Best Foreign Language film. Starring Gong Li as a young woman trapped in a loveless marriage, this sensual and striking film is aided by its vivid use of Technicolor.

constellations_other.name: Evolution of colour
constellations_other.description: From stenciling film frames through to the survival of Technicolor after Hollywood stopped using it, this Constellation links early cinema to some of the world's greatest films.

end.title: Resident Evil 2
end.brief_description: In Resident Evil 2, the classic action, tense exploration and puzzle solving gameplay that defined the Resident Evil series returns. Players join rookie police officer Leon Kennedy and college student Claire Redfield, who are thrust together by a zombie outbreak in Raccoon City.

constellations_other.name: Evolution of colour
constellations_other.description: From stenciling film frames through to the survival of Technicolor after Hollywood stopped using it, this Constellation links early cinema to some of the world's greatest films.

links.description: Technicolor discontinued its process again in 2002 after being bought by French company Thomson. But Thomson renamed itself Technicolor SA and is still involved in media production, helping make videogames like Capcom’s Resident Evil 2 remake.

start.brief_description: When Alexandre Volkoff brought the story of history’s greatest lover to the screen in Casanova (1927), he definitely needed colour. Pathé Frères developed a stencil technqiue for colouring films that brought Casanova’s costumes alive and colour to his lovers’ cheeks.

end.title: Loves of Casanova
end.creator_credit: Ciné-Alliance, Deulig Film, Société des Cinéromans, Noë Bloch, Alexandre Volkoff, Ivan Mosjoukine and Norbert Falk
end.brief_description: Republic of Venice, 1760. Pursued by a vengeful husband, the intrepid womanizer Casanova, who symbolizes the decline of the city and its fall into debauchery, manages to escape and, by a circuitous route, arrives in Saint Petersburg, where he will be involved in the many plots that threaten the throne of Czar Peter III…

constellations_other.name: Evolution of colour
constellations_other.description: From stenciling film frames through to the survival of Technicolor after Hollywood stopped using it, this Constellation links early cinema to some of the world's greatest films.

links.description: When Alexandre Volkoff brought the story of history’s greatest lover to the screen in Casanova (1927), he definitely needed colour, which he achieved through stenciling.

start.title: A Visit to the Seaside
start.brief_description: The first successful motion picture in the Kinemacolor system, this eight minute short from George Albert Smith showed people in Brighton, England doing everyday activities. Kinemacolor later influenced and was then replaced by Technicolor.

constellations_other.name: Evolution of colour
constellations_other.description: From stenciling film frames through to the survival of Technicolor after Hollywood stopped using it, this Constellation links early cinema to some of the world's greatest films.

end.title: Kinemacolor
end.brief_description: Kinemacolor was the most successful process for colouring early cinema. Invented in 1906 by film pioneer George Albert Smith, it achieved the illusion of colour by capturing and projecting black-and-white film through alternating red and green filters.

constellations_other.name: Evolution of colour
constellations_other.description: From stenciling film frames through to the survival of Technicolor after Hollywood stopped using it, this Constellation links early cinema to some of the world's greatest films.

links.description: Invented in 1906 by film pioneer George Albert Smith, Kinemacolor achieved the illusion of colour by capturing and projecting black-and-white film through alternating red and green filters. The first Kinemacolor film was A Visit to the Seaside.
